title: Turkey and Russia agree on Kurdish withdrawal, joint patrols in Syria
text:
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, left, meets with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin, right | Sergei Chirikov/AFP via Getty Images Turkey and Russia agree on Kurdish withdrawal, joint patrols in Syria Syrian Kurdish fighters will have 150 hours from noon on Wednesday to withdraw from areas near the border.

Ankara and Moscow have agreed that Syrian Kurdish fighters will withdraw from territory near the Turkish border and plan to conduct joint patrols in northern Syria, Turkey said Tuesday.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan met with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin in Sochi on Tuesday afternoon, hours before a U.S.-mediated ceasefire in northern Syria was due to expire.

Following lengthy talks between the two leaders, Erdoğan announced that they had struck an agreement that involves the Syrian Kurdish militia YPG moving 30 kilometers away from the Turkish-Syrian border and withdrawing from the key towns of Tel Rifaat and Manbij.

Kurdish fighters will have another 150 hours from Wednesday at noon to clear out of the areas mentioned in the agreement, a translated version of which was circulated to journalists by Turkish government officials.

After the withdrawal period, Turkey — a NATO member — and Russia will conduct joint patrols in part of the area.

According to the text, the agreement preserves "the established status quo" of the Turkish incursion, dubbed Operation Peace Spring.

"Starting 12.00 noon of October 23, 2019, Russian military police and Syrian border guards will enter the Syrian side of the Turkish-Syrian border ... to facilitate the removal of YPG elements and their weapons to the depth of 30 km from the Turkish-Syrian border, which should be finalized in 150 hours," the agreement says.

It adds: "At that moment, joint Russian-Turkish patrols will start in the west and the east of the area of Operation Peace Spring with a depth of 10 km, except Qamishli city," a major Kurdish-majority town in northeastern Syria.

Turkey launched the military operation — aimed against Syrian Kurdish fighters who became vital partners of the West in the fight against the Islamic State, but whom Ankara considers to be terrorists — two weeks ago, after the U.S. announced it would withdraw troops in the area.

The incursion displaced more than 100,000 people and left Syrian Kurds with little choice other than to ask the Moscow-backed regime of President Bashar al-Assad for help, effectively putting an end to their semi-autonomy.

Ankara also wants to establish a so-called "safe zone" in the areas it takes from the YPG to resettle refugees there. Turkey currently hosts some 3.5 million Syrians, and anti-refugee sentiment is on the rise.

The agreement text adds that Turkey and Russia will launch "joint efforts ... to facilitate the return of refugees in a safe and voluntary manner."
description: Syrian Kurdish fighters will have 150 hours from noon on Wednesday to withdraw from areas near the border.
